statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Nevada 74, Vermont 64
article.story: RENO, Nev. (AP) -- Nevada ensured its first back-to-back 20 win seasons in school history as Nick Fazekas scored 31 points and the Wolf Pack defense shut down Vermont's sharpshooters during the second half Saturday for a 74-64 victory. Fazekas, a 6-foot-11 sophomore, grabbed 14 rebounds, while freshman point guard Ramon Sessions added 16 points for the Wolf Pack, (20-5, 11-2 in the Western Athletic Conference). Nevada won its sixth in a row and eighth of its last nine games. "Their intensity was really the difference," Vermont Coach Tom Brennan said after one of the marquee matchups on ESPN's Bracket Buster. "We certainly played an NCAA Tournament team. There's no doubt about that." T.J. Sorrentine scored 24 points but was held to nine in the second half for the Catamounts (19-5, 14-1 in the America East Conference). Taylor Coppenrath, who entered the game ranked third in the nation averaging 24.1 points per game, finished with 18. Vermont made 7-of-13 3-point goals in the first half, with Sorrentine hitting all four of his shots, to take a 38-34 halftime lead but managed only 1-of-14 from behind the arc in the second half. Kyle Shiloh and Mo Charlo shadowed the star point guard, who was 1-of-4 from there after the break. "I felt like our defense was a big part of their misses," Nevada coach Mark Fox said. "They had seven 3-pointers at halftime, so we talked about defending the 3-point line. ... Kyle Shiloh deserves an unbelievable amount of credit as does Mo Charlo." Sessions scored 6 points and Fazekas 5 on a 13-4 run to open the second half and put Nevada ahead 47-42 with 14:50 left. Sorrentine cut through defenders for consecutive layups to pull Vermont to within 51-50 at 12:10. But Nevada answered with a 9-2 run to go up 60-52 on Charlo's bank shot at 7:34. Josh Duell hit from 17 feet and Coppenrath scored inside to cut the lead to 62-58 with 3:43 left. But Fazekas scored off a rebound and added a pair of free throws for a 67-60 lead at 1:47, and Charlo made four free throws and Sessions two in the final 46 seconds to secure the win. "I think they just wore us down a little bit and caused us to make mistakes," Brennan said about a Wolf Pack squad that last year had a first-ever trip to the NCAA Tourney's Sweet Sixteen. The Catamounts had 14 turnovers to Nevada's seven. Nevada held Coppenrath scoreless the first 8 minutes of the game and went ahead 20-17 on Fazekas' 3-pointer from the top of the key midway through the first half. Ryan Schneider and Sorrentine hit consecutive 3-point shots on an 8-0 run that put Vermont on top 25-20 at 7:52. Sorrentine made his fourth 3-pointer in as many tries for a 38-32 lead at 1:44 before Sessions' layup just before the half made it 38-34. Fazekas, who ranks 12th nationally averaging 20.9 points per game, was happy to see single man coverage after routinely facing double teams in WAC play. "I felt like I could score," said Fazekas, who was two points shy of his career high. "For me, someone to play one-on-one, I'm over there drooling over that. All WAC season I've been seeing double teams. I felt like I could do anything."
